content.content:
1â---
     2âtitle: "Webhooks"
     3âdescription: "Connect external systems to your agents using webhook endpoints"
     4âicon: "webhook"
     5â---
     6â
     7âWebhooks enable you to trigger xpander.ai agents from any external system that can make HTTP requests. Each agent has a unique webhook URL for programmatic interaction.
     8â
     9â## Accessing Your Webhook URL
    10â
    11â<Frame caption="Agent Builder Interface">
    12â![Agent Builder Interface](/static/images/screenshots/36DB40C0-7033-4F84-8CB8-EA1FAD14C561.png)
    13â</Frame>
    14â
    15âTo find your webhook URL:
    16â1. Navigate to your agent in the AI Agent Workbench
    17â2. Click the "Webhook" trigger in the top of the graph
    18â3. The Webhook Configuration panel will open, providing:
    19â   - Ready-to-use code snippets
    20â   - Configuration instructions
    21â   - Testing capabilities
    22â   - Webhook management options
    23â
    24â<Frame caption="Webhook Configuration Interface">
    25â![Webhook Configuration Interface](/static/images/screenshots/AECAB014-E97A-4D2C-BEDF-64118F45BD4D.png)
    26â</Frame>
    27â
    28â## Making Webhook Requests
    29â
    30â### Required Parameters
    31â
    32â| Parameter | Type | Description |
    33â| --------- | ---- | ----------- |
    34â| `agent_id` | string | The unique identifier of your agent |
    35â| `source_node_id` | string | The starting node ID in your agent's workflow |
    36â| `x-api-key` | string | Your API key for authentication (header or query parameter) |
    37â| `asynchronous` | boolean | Whether to wait for completion (`false`) or return immediately (`true`) |
    38â
    39â### Request Body Options
    40â
    41â| Option | Type | Description |
    42â| ------ | ---- | ----------- |
    43â| `files` | file | One or more files to process (PDF, PNG, JPEG, GIF, WEBP) |
    44â| `prompt` | string | A text prompt to send to the agent |
    45â
    46â<Warning>
    47âWhen uploading files, you must send the actual files using `multipart/form-data`. Direct external URLs to files are not supported as inputs. The platform will generate secure presigned URLs for your agent to access the uploaded files.
    48â</Warning>
    49â
    50â### Content Types
    51â
    52â- **With files**: Use `multipart/form-data` (curl handles this automatically with `--form`)
    53â- **JSON only**: Use `application/json` with the appropriate header
    54â
    55â## File Handling
    56â
    57â### Supported File Types
    58â
    59âxpander.ai supports a variety of file formats:
    60â- Documents: PDF
    61â- Images: PNG, JPEG, GIF, WEBP
    62â
    63â### Uploading Multiple Files
    64â
    65âTo process multiple files in a single request:
    66â
    67â```bash
    68âcurl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=true" \
    69â--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
    70â--form "prompt=Process these documents" \
    71â--form "files=@/path/to/first-file.pdf" \
    72â--form "files=@/path/to/second-file.pdf" \
    73â--form "files=@/path/to/image.png" \
    74â--form "source_node_id=YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID" \
    75â--form "agent_id=YOUR_AGENT_ID"
    76â```
    77â
    78âFor large batches of files (10+ files), we recommend:
    79â1. Using asynchronous mode (`asynchronous=true`)
    80â2. Breaking uploads into multiple requests of 5-10 files each
    81â3. Using a dedicated file uploader with retry capabilities
    82â
    83â### File URL Mechanism
    84â
    85âWhen you upload files through the webhook:
    86â
    87â1. xpander.ai automatically handles storage of your files
    88â2. Your agent receives secure presigned URLs to access these files
    89â3. These URLs remain valid for 30 days after upload
    90â4. Files are accessible only to your organization's agents
    91â
    92â<Info>
    93âAll uploaded files are stored securely on our platform. Your agent doesn't need to handle file storage or download logic - it will automatically receive properly formatted URLs to access the files.
    94â</Info>
    95â
    96â## Synchronous vs Asynchronous Requests
    97â
    98â### Synchronous Mode
    99â
   100â```bash
   101âcurl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=false" \
   102â--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
   103â--header "Content-Type: application/json" \
   104â--data '{"source_node_id": "YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID", "agent_id": "YOUR_AGENT_ID", "prompt": "What can you do?"}'
   105â```
   106â
   107â- HTTP request remains open until agent completes
   108â- Returns complete execution details and results
   109â- Best for immediate responses and short tasks
   110â
   111â**Response:**
   112â
   113â```json
   114â{
   115â  "result": {
   116â    "id": "9642f5dd-e535-465f-bdaf-89be6ecaa2d5",
   117â    "status": "completed",
   118â    "result": "I specialize in extracting text from image and PDF files using Optical Character Recognition (OCR) technology. If you provide me with a file in a supported format (pdf, png, jpeg, gif, webp), I can extract the text content for you.",
   119â    "source": "webhook"
   120â  }
   121â}
   122â```
   123â
   124â### Asynchronous Mode
   125â
   126â```bash
   127âcurl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=true" \
   128â--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
   129â--header "Content-Type: application/json" \
   130â--data '{"source_node_id": "YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID", "agent_id": "YOUR_AGENT_ID", "prompt": "What can you do?"}'
   131â```
   132â
   133â- Returns immediately while agent processes in background
   134â- Best for long-running tasks and large file processing
   135â- Allows your application to continue execution
   136â
   137â**Response:**
   138â
   139â```json
   140â{
   141â  "result": "Started"
   142â}
   143â```
   144â
   145â## Example: OCR Document Processing
   146â
   147âThis example shows how to extract text from a document using the OCR agent:
   148â
   149â```bash
   150âcurl --location "https://webhook.xpander.ai?asynchronous=false" \
   151â--header "x-api-key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
   152â--form "prompt=Extract text from this document" \
   153â--form "files=@/path/to/your/document.pdf" \
   154â--form "source_node_id=YOUR_SOURCE_NODE_ID" \
   155â--form "agent_id=YOUR_AGENT_ID"
   156â```
   157â
   158â<Info>
   159âThe OCR agent handles multiple document formats (PDFs and images) and preserves formatting when possible, including tables and structured content.
   160â</Info>
   161â
   162â### Sample OCR Result
   163â
   164â```json
   165â{
   166â  "result": {
   167â    "id": "07d6f375-53e9-4aa3-a7af-c36ce99a07d8",
   168â    "status": "completed",
   169â    "result": "## Financial Statement\n\n## ACCOUNT SUMMARY FOR PERIOD ENDED SEPTEMBER 30, 2024\n\n| Description | Amount | Percentage |\n|------------|--------|------------|\n| Opening Balance | 50,000 | - |\n| Deposits | 25,000 | - |\n| Withdrawals | (10,000) | - |\n| Fees | (1,500) | 3% |\n| Interest | 1,200 | 2.4% |\n| Closing Balance | 64,700 | - |",
   170â    "source": "webhook"
   171â  }
   172â}
   173â```
   174â
   175â## Monitoring Webhook Activity
   176â
   177âxpander.ai provides a comprehensive monitoring interface for webhook calls:
   178â
   179â<Frame caption="Webhook Monitoring Interface">
   180â![OCR Agent Monitoring Interface](/static/images/screenshots/858B1698-A13F-4B6B-9ADB-71629B4BD261.png)
   181â</Frame>
   182â
   183âThe monitoring dashboard displays:
   184â- Complete execution logs
   185â- File processing details
   186â- Performance metrics
   187â- Full request/response data
   188â
   189â## Common Use Cases
   190â
   191â<CardGroup cols={2}>
   192â  <Card title="Workflow Automation" icon="robot">
   193â    Integrate with platforms like Zapier, Make.com, or n8n to trigger document processing based on external events.
   194â  </Card>
   195â  
   196â  <Card title="Document Processing" icon="file-pdf">
   197â    Extract structured data from documents to automate data entry and analysis workflows.
   198â  </Card>
   199â</CardGroup>

---
title: "Quickstart - CLI"
description: "Get started with xpander.ai and build your first AI agent"
icon: "terminal"
---

## Installation and Configuration

<Steps>
  <Step title="Install the CLI">
    Install the xpander CLI globally:

    ```bash
    npm install -g xpander-cli
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure your credentials">
    Set up your API key and organization:

    ```bash
    xpander configure
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example configuration output">
    ```
    You need to configure your credentials to use the Xpander CLI.
    ? Would you like to configure your credentials now? Yes
    ? Enter your Xpander API key: IhPLk2Cu5BXw5BmVBhld3p31mTpAxC892pD6O5E3
    API Key: IhPL...O5E3 (first and last 4 characters shown)
    â API key validation successful
    API key saved to profile "default".
    Organization ID will be auto-detected for you now...
    â  Detecting organization ID...Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Organization ID saved to profile "default".
    â Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Found 1 agent(s) in your organization.
    Set "default" as the default profile.
    Credentials stored at: /Users/david/.xpander/credentials
    Profile: default

    Configuration successful.
    ```
    </Accordion>
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Creating Your First Agent

<Steps>
  <Step title="Create a new agent">
    Create your agent using the CLI:

    ```bash
    xpander agent new
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example agent creation output">
    ```
    â¨ Agent Creation Wizard â¨
    ââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââ
    Create a powerful AI agent for your organization
    ââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââ

    ? What name would you like for your agent? my-first-agent

    Name:     my-first-agent
    ID:       4fe1163d-bb00-4837-9e25-6f82aed8038c
    Icon:     ð
    Model:    openai/gpt-4.1
    ââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââ

    â Agent creation complete!

    ? Do you want to load this agent into your current workdir? Yes


    â¨ Initializing agent

    </Accordion>
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure environment variables">
    Create a `.env` file in the root directory with the following credentials:

    ```txt .env file
    XPANDER_API_KEY=your_xpander_api_key  # From the xpander login output
    OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key
    OPENAI_MODEL_ID=gpt-4.1
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Working with Your Agent

With your agent created, you can now work with it in several ways:

1. **Using the SDK in your code**: Implement the agent loop and integrate with your application
2. **Stream events from the cloud**: Set up a handler to receive events from xpander.ai
3. **Deploy to the cloud**: Host your agent in the xpander.ai cloud

For detailed code examples and step-by-step implementation instructions, see our dedicated [Instrument & Run AI Agents](/docs/01-get-started/03-instrument-agents) guide.

    12â

---
title: "Module 2: SWE task management UI"
description: "Use a lightweight ChatGPT-Codex style UI to submit a coding task to your SWE agent"
icon: "desktop"
---

<Note>
In this module, we deploy a custom UI that is similar to the capabilities you get with ChatGPT-Codex, connect it to Agent Backend, and we will submit development tasks while we explore how the agent is working.
</Note>

**Goal**: Build a full-stack coding agent (Frontend and Backend) and task it to write an application and send a PR completely autonomously

## Step 1: GitHub Manual Fork

To submit a PR with your generated app to the apps-by-agents repository, first fork the repo:

1. Go to https://github.com/xpander-ai/apps-by-agents
2. Fork the repo to your GitHub account

## Step 2: Clone the frontend example app

Weâll start by cloning and installing the pre-built UI:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/xpander-ai/coding-agent-frontend-example-app.git
cd coding-agent-frontend-example-app
npm install
```

## Step 3: Configure environment variables

Copy the example .env file and populate it

```bash
mv .env.example .env
```

## Step 4: Connect the Frontend to the Agent Backend

In the frontend application, go to the `.env` file and fill in the following:

```env
# API Key - Available in CLI output
VITE_APP_API_KEY=your_api_key_here
# Agent ID - Available in CLI output
VITE_APP_AGENT_ID=your_agent_id_here
# Organization ID - Available in the CLI output
VITE_APP_ORGANIZATION_ID=your_organization_id_here
```

## Step 5: Start the frontend app

Launch the demo app locally:

```bash
npm run dev
```

![Step 3 - npm run dev](/images/workshops/swe-npm-run-dev.png)

Then navigate to:

```
http://localhost:3000
```

Your AI Agent's task management demo app:
![Step 3 - Open Browser](/images/workshops/swe-blank-tasks-manager.png)

<Note>
  If you have already downloaded the Agent code using the xpander cli `xpander init`, ensure that xpander_handler.py is running. Otherwise, events will be routed to the serverless hosting.
</Note>

## Step 6: Send coding tasks

Your local task management demo app is now connected to the SWE agent you deployed in the last module. Let's start using it.

In the input field, submit one of the example prompts below

<Note>
In the Task management app Web UI, submit the prompt and mention your forked repo

For example:

"Add a simple, cool, and beautiful todo list app (HTML, CSS, JS) to `my-github-user-name/apps-by-agents` in one-shot, single commit."

Your coding agent will push the app to your forked repo, afterwards you'll create a PR to the original repo.
</Note>

Feel free to be creative, but specify that it should be an (HTML, CSS, JS) app, and mention the address of your forked repo

<Accordion title="Prompt Examples for apps-by-agents">

### â Todo List App
```text
Add a simple, cool, and beautiful todo list app (HTML, CSS, JS) to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### â±ï¸ Pomodoro Timer

```text
Add a minimal Pomodoro timer app (HTML, CSS, JS) to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð¦ï¸ Weather Dashboard

```text
Build a weather dashboard using OpenWeatherMap API (HTML, CSS, JS) and add it to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð Markdown Editor

```text
Create a simple markdown editor with live preview (HTML, CSS, JS) and save it in https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð§® Calculator App

```text
Generate a calculator app with keyboard support (HTML, CSS, JS) and store in https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð Landing Page

```text
Add a responsive landing page template with Tailwind CSS to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð¬ Chatbot UI

```text
Create a basic chatbot UI (HTML, CSS, JS) with a placeholder for messages and append it to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð¨ Color Palette Generator

```text
Build a color palette generator that shows hex codes (HTML, CSS, JS) and commit to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð Unit Converter

```text
Develop a unit converter (length, weight, temperature) as a single-page app and push to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### â¨ï¸ Typing Speed Test

```text
Add a typing speed test app (HTML, CSS, JS) to https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

### ð Memory Card Matching Game

```text
Create a memory card matching game (HTML, CSS, JS) and drop it into https://github.com/`<your fork address>` in one-shot, single commit.
```

</Accordion>

<Frame>
  <video autoPlay muted loop playsInline className="w-full aspect-video" src="https://assets.xpanderai.io/workshops/videos/swe-send-task.mp4" />
</Frame>

---

## Step 7: Track task execution

Click **View codex logs** to view real-time execution details and explore the logs.
Pay attention to the way Codex manages and runs the agentic loop and the creation process of your app.

> â³ **Note**: Task execution takes a few minutes - sit back, relax, and watch the agent work its magic. Codex may split the task into multiple sub-tasks that can take up to 15 minutes. If it takes more than 15 minutes, just let it run in the background and proceed with the rest of the workshop.

<Frame>
  <video autoPlay muted loop playsInline className="w-full aspect-video" src="https://assets.xpanderai.io/workshops/videos/swe-track-result.mp4" />
</Frame>

Youâll see:

- **Top**: The original prompt or task
- **Popup**: Logs and generated output from the agent
- **Result**: Execution result
- **Logs & Messages Buttons**: Execution messages logs & codex execution logs

<Accordion title="How does this work?">

  When you submit a task, the app uses the **xpander.ai SDK** (via a **Web Worker**) to create and run the task in the cloud - fully serverless.

  The worker handles:
  - Creating tasks â [`createTask()` in `workers/xpanderWorker.ts`](https://github.com/xpander-ai/coding-agent-frontend-example-app/blob/main/src/workers/xpanderWorker.ts#L79)
  - Fetching task details and logs â [`useTask()` and `useLogs()` in `hooks/`](https://github.com/xpander-ai/coding-agent-frontend-example-app/tree/main/src/hooks)

  The UI polls task status and updates in real time using **React Query**.  
  You can see this in action inside:
  - [`Dashboard`](https://github.com/xpander-ai/coding-agent-frontend-example-app/blob/main/src/pages/Dashboard.tsx): task list and creation
  - [`TaskDetails`](https://github.com/xpander-ai/coding-agent-frontend-example-app/blob/main/src/pages/TaskDetails.tsx): real-time updates, logs, messages

  The **Codex tool** streams logs to a centralized **Logstash** tied to your **account**.  
  Logs are stored for a limited period and made available via the `logs.xpander.ai` micro-service.

  The frontend fetches these logs through polling (every 2s) using the SDK inside a Web Worker.

  ð¡ A task can include multiple threads - each representing a conversation or execution chain tied to your agent.
</Accordion>

Successful app creation

![swe coding task result with pr](/images/workshops/swe-coding-task-result-with-pr.png)

<Note>
Pay attention, your PR is targeting the fork and not xpander's repo
</Note>

## Summary and next steps

Your SWE task management UI is now live and connected to the SWE agent hosted on xpander.ai.
Through the UI, you instructed the agent to build an application and push it to the apps-by-agents repo.

â Proceed to [Module 3: Advanced customization](./03-advanced-customization)

You are now seeing the AI Workbench - a user interface used to design, deploy, test and observe agents.

<Frame>

Give the Agent permissions to use GitHub

Click on "Authorization required" in the tools view of the agent and complete the OAuth flow.

Change the view to **Agent Graph** to see the visual representation of your agent or multi-agent team, including its different triggering capabilities and its available tools.

Check out the available tools your agent has. It can interact with GitHub - listing, creating, updating, and commenting on pull requests. More importantly, it can code using the built-in Coding agent, built on an enhanced version of Codex CLI.

<Frame>
![Serverless coding agent](/images/workshops/serverless-coding-agent.png)
</Frame>


<Warning>If the GitHub tools on the graph are displaying a red exclamation mark, it's because you still need to authorize the GitHub connector. Click on the exclamation mark and go through the Auth process with OAuth2</Warning>


<Accordion title="Codex CLI built into the agent?">

  The **Coding Agent** runs on **GPT-4.1** and handles high-level reasoning, task planning, and decision-making.  
  It uses tools to complete actions - one of them being the **Codex tool**.

  The **Codex tool** is a containerized, sandboxed version of the **Codex CLI**, running with the agentâs own **Git credentials**.  
  It's powered by the **codex-mini-latest** model, optimized for fast, focused code generation.

  The agent sends coding tasks to this tool - for example, âadd tests for this functionâ - and the Codex tool writes or modifies the code.  
  Combined with the **GitHub integration**, the agent can autonomously list, create, update, and comment on pull requests.

</Accordion>

## Step 2: Test your agent using the visual AI Workbench

Letâs walk through a real GitHub workflow using your agent

---
title: "Quickstart - CLI"
description: "Get started with xpander.ai and build your first AI agent"
icon: "terminal"
---

## Installation and Configuration

<Steps>
  <Step title="Install the CLI">
    Install the xpander CLI globally:

    ```bash
    npm install -g xpander-cli
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure your credentials">
    Set up your API key and organization:

    ```bash
    xpander configure
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example configuration output">
    ```
    You need to configure your credentials to use the Xpander CLI.
    ? Would you like to configure your credentials now? Yes
    ? Enter your Xpander API key: IhPLk2Cu5BXw5BmVBhld3p31mTpAxC892pD6O5E3
    API Key: IhPL...O5E3 (first and last 4 characters shown)
    â API key validation successful
    API key saved to profile "default".
    Organization ID will be auto-detected for you now...
    â  Detecting organization ID...Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Organization ID saved to profile "default".
    â Organization ID detected: 8d185373-8b24-47a7-8607-3e9036b968bb
    Found 1 agent(s) in your organization.
    Set "default" as the default profile.
    Credentials stored at: /Users/david/.xpander/credentials
    Profile: default

    Configuration successful.
    ```
    </Accordion>
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Creating Your First Agent

<Steps>
  <Step title="Create a new agent">
    Create your agent using the CLI:

    ```bash
    xpander agent new
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example agent creation output">
    ```
    â¨ Agent Creation Wizard â¨

    Create a powerful AI agent for your organization
    ââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââ

    â Agent "my-first-agent" created successfully!

    ð Your Agent is Ready!

    Name:     my-first-agent
    ID:       4fe1163d-bb00-4837-9e25-6f82aed8038c
    Icon:     ð
    Model:    openai/gpt-4.1
    ââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââ

    </Accordion>
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure environment variables">
    Create a `.env` file in the root directory with the following credentials:

    ```txt .env file
    XPANDER_API_KEY=your_xpander_api_key  # From the xpander login output
    OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key
    OPENAI_MODEL_ID=gpt-4.1
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Working with Your Agent

With your agent created, you can now work with it in several ways:

1. **Using the SDK in your code**: Implement the agent loop and integrate with your application
2. **Stream events from the cloud**: Set up a handler to receive events from xpander.ai
3. **Deploy to the cloud**: Host your agent in the xpander.ai cloud

For detailed code examples and step-by-step implementation instructions, see our dedicated [Instrument & Run AI Agents](/docs/01-get-started/03-instrument-agents) guide.

icon: "terminal"

## Installation and Configuration

<Steps>
  <Step title="Install the CLI">
    Install the xpander CLI globally (current version: v0.0.37):

    ```bash
    npm install -g xpander-cli
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step title="Configure your credentials">
    Set up your API key and organization:

    ```bash
    xpander configure
    ```

    <Accordion title="Example configuration output">
    ```
    You need to configure your credentials to use the Xpander CLI.
    ? Would you like to configure your credentials now? Yes

    Organization ID saved to profile "default".

    Found 1 agent(s) in your organization.
    Set "default" as the default profile.
    Credentials stored at: /Users/david/.xpander/credentials
    Profile: default

    Configuration successful.
    ```
    </Accordion>
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Creating Your First Agent

<Steps>
  <Step title="Create a new agent">
    Create your agent using the CLI with template selection:

    ```bash
    xpander agent new
    ```

    The CLI will guide you through:
    1. **Agent naming**: Choose a descriptive name for your agent
    2. **Template selection**: Choose from available templates including:
       - **Basic Agent**: Simple agent with core functionality
       - **Agno Framework**: Multi-agent system using the Agno Python framework
       - **Custom**: Start with a blank template for full customization
    3. **Configuration**: Set up initial agent settings and capabilities

  <Step title="Configure environment variables">
    Create a `.env` file in the root directory with the following credentials:

    ```txt .env file
    XPANDER_API_KEY=your_xpander_api_key  # From the xpander login output
    OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key
    OPENAI_MODEL_ID=gpt-4.1
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Working with Your Agent

With your agent created, you can now work with it in several ways:

1. **Using the SDK in your code**: Implement the agent loop and integrate with your application
2. **Stream events from the cloud**: Set up a handler to receive events from xpander.ai
3. **Deploy to the cloud**: Host your agent in the xpander.ai cloud

For detailed code examples and step-by-step implementation instructions, see our dedicated [Instrument & Run AI Agents](/docs/01-get-started/03-instrument-agents) guide.

    XPANDER_API_KEY=your_xpander_api_key  # From the xpander login output
    OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key
    OPENAI_MODEL_ID=gpt-4.1
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Working with Your Agent

With your agent created, you can now work with it in several ways:

1. **Using the SDK in your code**: Implement the agent loop and integrate with your application
2. **Stream events from the cloud**: Set up a handler to receive events from xpander.ai
3. **Deploy to the cloud**: Host your agent in the xpander.ai cloud

For detailed code examples and step-by-step implementation instructions, see our dedicated [Instrument & Run AI Agents](/docs/01-get-started/03-instrument-agents) guide.

### Template Selection Details

    When creating a new agent, you'll be prompted to select from these templates:

    <CardGroup cols={3}>
      <Card title="Basic Agent" icon="robot">
        A simple agent with core functionality and basic tools. Perfect for getting started quickly.
      </Card>
      
      <Card title="Agno Framework" icon="network-wired">
        Multi-agent system using the Agno Python framework. Ideal for complex workflows requiring multiple coordinated agents.
      </Card>
      
      <Card title="Custom Template" icon="wrench">
        Start with a blank template for full customization. Best for experienced users with specific requirements.
      </Card>
    </CardGroup>

    <Note>
    The **Agno Framework** template is particularly powerful for building complex multi-agent systems. Agno is a Python framework that enables sophisticated agent coordination, making it perfect for enterprise workflows that require multiple specialized agents working together.
    </Note>

  </Step>
